The origional release of Gauntlet was awesome!  For some reason they changed it to 'slayer edition' took away all the custom elements and created a dumbed down version of somthing that coulda been great.

I wont recommend this game to someone looking for a Gauntlet game, but if it's on sale for like $10, id say go for it.  On one hand, the game isn't a 'bad game,' except for the fact that there are only three areas, which was an enormous disappointment to me when i walked forqard and back thinking i had just missed them. On the other hand, this game is not the Gauntlet you probably know and love. The whole new character design thing is lame, Gauntlet didn't need that type of gameplay.  Then theres the part where there really aren't any items because you get these sort of bonus skills (which are the only thing you use gold for) which are activated by potions (which is the only thing you use potions for). Keys don't roll over after you've completed a level, and neither do potions, and theres really no reason to ever worry about having the exact number of them, you might just miss one or two doors with some gold behind them, which is relatively pointless and not even remotely exciting anyways.  It feels like someone who hasn't played Gauntlet much just took the project and went 'Hey, guys, hear me out, I think people want this kind of game!'   All things considered, I didn't go through it hating my life, but I would give it a better ratying if it didn't pretend to be a Gauntlet game. And, again, why so few areas, that really bugs me. I feel like if I paid $10, or $15 i would be okay with it, but I didn't, so I'm not.

Game is basically ruined. They removed the unfair difficulty setting which was where 99% of the fun was. They also removed the leveling system that improves your character after defeating x amount of different types of monsters. I spent 97 hours according to Steam improving my characters and just had that returned to me as a paltry amount of in-game (read: completely worthless) gold.  Do NOT recommend.

Pros: The game looks and runs great. I haven't seen any bugs or had any crashes yet. It is very fun for the first 3-4 hours.   CONS:  It is extremely repetative. The 'puzzles' are easy and you don't have to think twice about using a key.  The characters AREN'T balanced. The melee characters need a complete rehaul. You can literately get stun locked when you use warrior. If you get hit once as the warrior, there is no way to escape and you can bounce around and get hit 2 3 sometimes 4 times and die. 90% of the time you are running away, kiting as a melee character.  THERE IS NO END GAME. You work towards your relic, which is the only thing you can customize besides cosmetics. BUT GUESS WHAT? You can't actually use your relic during the boss fights!! ALSO you can only use it 2 MAYBE 3 times during a dungeon with the way they have it set up.   All in all, it is a fun game for a couple of hours. Maybe a weekend fling. But there is absolutely no more then 7 maybe 8 hours of fun. $20 is too much. 6/10

The gameplay, visuals, and skills were very neat. The game deffinetly had the old gauntlet feel to it. That being said, this game was so short... I think it took about 4 hours to beat the game, it seems the makers of this game literally pulled a Diablo on us and gave a short game with the ability to play it over and over again to unlock ♥♥♥♥♥♥ items. Gauntlet Dark Legends which was presented on the Playstation 2 had more playable hours then this and the memory space available was tiny.  TL;DR This game is not worth your 20 dollars, it is another fine example for how companies overcharge for games that are not yet finished yet or are half ♥♥♥ representations of what they are meant to be.

Sadly dissapointing. Gauntlet has evolved with every game with new leveling systems, character customization, and even unique hidden characters, but this is just a crash from all of that.  It's a dungeon crawler with little to no player/class customization, No shop, no leveling, no, uniqueness, no hidden classes or special chalolenges that made all the predecessors so amazingly addictive.   Fair graphics, good voice acting, fair game controls, and decent music. 5 Hours to beat, more fun with others, but that's it. Just has a sprinkle, a flavor of Gauntlet. It is that succulant roast.. With a wretched arrow in it!

I was excited to see Gauntlet, but expected something as legendary as Gauntlet Legends 64. Unfortunately what I got was Gauntlet. It's a simple enough game, beat down waves of enemies to advance through dungeons, faces bosses, and then the game ends. I believe there are a total of 9 dungeons with 3 boss battles. A variety in gameplay can be achieved by making the game more or less difficult, but the dungeons will always be the same, enemies the same (but harder to kill), spawns the same, you get the point.  Finding players seems to be difficult to find, on launch I could find lobbies within a few seconds or have players fill my lobby in a few minutes. Now to fill your lobby could take twenty minutes, and finding a lobby will more likely take you into a lobby already in progress.  Could have been amazing, but was instead a four-hour distraction with little in way of replayability. That replayability is taken away more by no one willing to play. Save your money, or go get an N64 and buy Gauntlet Legends 64, which was an epic adventure with many levels, hours of gameplay and a great variety in enemies and locations.

I played the original Gauntlet local co-op with my brother regularly as a child. I find that this remake has stayed true to the concept and I have enjoyed it now twice all the way through. First time was normal mode solo, and then hard mode with my brother (ah, the nostalgia of playing the original!). This game is fairly short - about 5-6 hours. There is a lot of reason to replay this game though: you can level up each of the four classes, upgrade items and gear for up to all four classes, have fun playing with friends and even try to break the speed run records and score records. There are also 5 skill modes ranging from easy to unfair!  On the downside, there is absolutely no text or voice chat within the game so it can be annoying if you ever need to talk to a party member, especially if by allowing public to join your lobby. If you plan to co-op with friends steam chat and/or steam voice chat (or 3rd party software) are the only ways to communicate without any chat functions in-game.  All in all, I really enjoyed playing this game twice and would play it again if another friend wants to co-op through it.

A fun overhead-view twin-stick game. Each character has a very different playstyle with extra variety built in as you unlock different weapons for them. Multiple difficulty levels too.  The game is also simple. It isn't some in-depth role playing game. Its just a dungeon-crawler, with the primary element being slaughtering crowds of monsters. Before too long, you have seen it all.
good stuff for couch-coop. Would like to see more games like this for PC

I really don't understand why there are so many good reviews. This game is boring. I didn't played the original Gauntlet.  - You fight waves of the same ennemies again and again - Levels feel like copy paste. - Useless expensive equipment, give no stats, you just have to chose only 2 relics (10 total) that are the same for every classes. 0 feeling of progress. - 0 synergy between classes. - 'Epic bosses' what a joke, bosses are so uninspired. - The camera is so annoying - You can pick health when you are full, really ? You get rewarded to kill your friends, so many good idea for a co-op game... - Classes are not balanced. - No control rebind. - Short game, not enough content for a 20€ game.  I am sure i forget things. I mean when you see Hammerwatch for 9€, i do not recommend Gauntlet.

It's not a badly executed game, and the combat is quite nice... It's just i lose my interest everytime after a few levels because there is just not enough incentive leveling your character or gaining gold, which feels pretty useless after you unlocked the few and only skills your character has, without the possibility of upgrading it. A decent upgrade or leveling path feels like a huge omission for what could have been a great game considering the execution of everything they DID right. Fun maybe for a few hours, but gets old too quickly unfortunately.

So 3 of my friends and myself gave the game a go last night. For $15 bucks (each) and based on past Gauntlet games {Legends and Legacy} we figured it was worth a go. Traditional Gauntlet games get a ton of replay value so the $15 should merit that. In either case let me break into the actual review  Gauntlet starts you off by having you play each class; Warrior, Valkyrie, Elf/Archer and Wizard.  Warrior plays like in the typical hack and slash style. Valkyrie feel very Captain America'esc but still hack and slashy. Elf/Archer plays like a character from Smash TV. Lastly Wizard plays like Invoker from Dota 2 (to elaborate you have 9 spells and based on what elements you combine {Lightning, Fire, Ice} you get a different spell with each spell having its own cooldown). With each unique character you sort of get a different button schema. Where Warrior and Valkyrie (I might need clarification on this) smash buttons. The Elf/Archer and Wizard utilize the right analog.  Once you go through the tutorial you have the ability to start a game or begin a lobby. The lobby system is fantastic. There's no shift tabbing into the steam community to select a person's profile to invite them into a game. You simple click the button to open lobby (for me it was 'Y' on the Xbox control or 'X' on the PS3 based on the conversation software). and it brought up a list of friends currently playing Gauntlet who I could invite. The only gief is I wish it only brought up friends who have / are playing Gauntlet. I still get my full list of steam list friends which I think is silly.  Each selection is unique so can't have two Warriors or Valkyries etc. Once your in the game you have worlds to choose from... there's only 3 worlds with 4 levels so that was sort of a let down from the get go.  Also in the lobby you decide on your difficult. Easy is like a light version of Normal so you have more health and monsters are not as strong. Normal you get infinite number of re-spawns. Hard requires that you have tokens to re-spawn other players and Unfair you simply don't re-spawn and food rarely/never(?) exist. We went with Normal for our play-through.  There's also a shop that sells artifacts however to use the artifacts you must use potions you find in the level. So potions are no longer a generic AOE effect but are used in conjunction with artifacts. Shops items can also be upgraded and few items no longer have the 'one time use' feel. This gives potions sort of a customized feel however ultimately make them useless on boss as no potions spawn on those fights.  Another thing that doesn't exist in the shop now is 'stats'. 'Stats' or any sort of character enhancement is gained by spamming a specific character skill (typically bound to a button or in the Wizards case combine two buttons to make a spell). Other character enhancements (which are called Masteries) are gained through eating food, dying and collecting gold provide a passive bonus rather than active.  As to the actually game play...it felt super linear at first and unfortunately stayed that way for most of the game. There was very few 'whoops we went the wrong way' or 'did we miss something'. If such situations occurred it was a result of a bad camera angle hiding a wall that wasn't visible rather than a puzzle to figure out.  There's of course game elements to try to lighten the mood like players can light barrels of TNT on fire and throw it at friends or destroy food that a friend is about to pick up. There's also preset emotes that players can spam at each other. While were on emotes the characters periodically compliment each other when they get a long kill streak...this is 'cute' at first but due to its frequency gets old fast. The last sort interactive element was the crown which when worn gives the player at the end a gold bonus. However if they get hit the crown drops and another player can pick it up.  Level 1 and 2 of each world was typically presenting the theme. Level 3 was typically a small boss battle arena and level 4 was purely focused on the boss. Bosses were a hybrid of spamming the attack key and figuring out puzzles.  So general flow of the game was 'pick a world' -> 'pick a level' -> 'playthrough it' -> 'return to town' -> 'debating on buying artifacts' -> 'pick a world' repeat.  Now with all that said would I recommend picking up the game... probably not at it's current release price or I would definitely split the $15 bucks among several people and play it via Local. Even then not enough bang for the buck for me to recommend it.  As a group of 4 players we beat the game in about 4.3 hours. It really emphasizes on 'party play' and I could see it getting frustrating solo. There's no 'true' leveling system so you don't really feel the progression. You get a new skill to spam or your cool downs on a spell are reduced but your overall power still feels 'fixed'. As I mentioned before there are 'artifacts' that you can buy with gold earned in game but they are nothing game breaking.  Once you complete the game you do unlock cosmetic items however they require that you use in-game gold to buy them... so your reward for completing the game on a certain difficulty is unlocking an item in which you have to grind the levels you just beat to get the gold to buy the cosmetic item....yeah...no.  On a few minor notes there's a few times where death shows up which leads to comical deaths (Death no longer drains he simple kills you) but is quickly forgotten. There's no alternative classes like Tigress, Jester, Minotaur and etc. After we finished playing we expected that they would be DLC or something silly. Pojo (aka EGG911) is not in the game as well as 'X IS NOW IT' system is out as well.  The novelty and hopefully nostalgia you hope to draw out the game is typically gone after the first few hours. At its core it took what made the Gauntlet series unique and made it feel like a generic hack and slash.  Oh one last thing before I close this out...the soundtrack is okay but nothing stellar or to write home about.  Edits below (due to comments section limitation of 1,000 characters or less)  Response to Jareth Gawain on 09/28/2014:  Correct Jareth Gawain however I find that overall it pulls more aspects from Legends and Legacy then the original Gauntlet.   The original Gauntlet arcade aspects that differed it from other hack and slash/beat-'em-up arcade games at that time was the concept of a time limit. Players health totals constantly dropped and there weren't many/any titles prior to this that forced players to find a way to conclude the level in an effective manner. This game mechanic at the time was complimented by a labyrinth-esc design which futher penalized player for making an incorrect choice for not finding the right way out. Am I saying that such a mechanic(s) should have been implemented into Gauntlet™?  Absolutely not or rather if they did so perhaps it happens on a higher difficulty. As I stated I did not play on anything higher than 'Normal' so this may already maybe implemented in the game. The above game mechanic(s) I didn't feel in Gauntlet™. The game felt very linear and more Legends/Legacy then the arcade versions.  To the point regarding Legends and/or Legacys I felt Gauntlet™ drew more from these mondern versions than its predecessors. Concepts of character progression, item shops, boss battles, quotes such as 'needs food badly' and many others pull from the days of Legends and/or Legacy. Which to me as a individual playing the game I think is a good thing that they didn't try to keep the pure rustic feel of the past in Gauntlet™. For these above reasons I feel Gauntlet™ feels more like Legends and/or Legacy than the original arcade boot.

Had high hopes that this reboot would bring back the classic Gauntlet experience. I just don't feel it's worth the $20 when It can easily be completed in under 5 hours. The developers could have packed a bit more stages and wider variety of monsters to slash through before releasing this. I won't say it's a bad game, just lacking content. And there is no reason you should be able to destroy food. Sorry, I can't recommend this game to anyone whose played the previous Gauntlet titles, It's missing a lot of features.. :/

If you've played past Gauntlet games you'll come to realize shortly after starting the tutorial stage that this is almost   NOTHING   like past games of the series.   The only things that I found similar are:   4 Player Co-Op    The announcer exclaims things like. 'Your health is getting low!'   Oh you shot the food? It's gone now.   Secret passages   RUN FROM DEATH   Things missing from past Gauntlet games:   Persistant Stats. The armor from the shop? Yeah it's cosmetic.   Buying benificial shop items. Besides the stat boosts which is obviously gone. You also can't buy magic potions, halos, that little Phoenix that would follow you around and add projectiles on top of your own attacks. Yeah none of that exists. You can only buy 'relics' now.   No shield button. That's gone too. One class has a shield. The others have different abilities like charge or a dodge roll. Wizard doesn't have any of those. But he does have a spell shield he can cast that breaks after a short duration.   Things that are largely different from past Gauntlet games:   Characters have a skill that goes on cooldown and a couple benificial abilities instead of a basic attack that would automatically choose a ranged or melee attack.   Magic potions don't damage things on the screen. Now they're used to power 'relic' items you purchase with gold from the shop. Not necessarily as great or had the same powerful impact as dropping a lightning potion on the screen and frying things to a crisp.    TL;DR If you have never played a Gauntlet game. You might actually find this game is eh, alright. Not terrible. But not great either.  But if you're a past Gauntlet fan. Look elsewhere. Holy crap. They just plastered the title 'Gauntlet' on this. I bought into it like a fool. Don't make the same mistake I did.

It's a good game but all you see in the trailer is all the game is. There's nothing else because this is a short game. I would recommend it for 5 bucks but not more because Gauntlet can't offer more than 8-10 fun hours. It would be an awesome game if it had more content but it only has 3 quick areas... it's not worth the money.

If you are a fan of Gauntlet Legends for the N64, this game is a total let down! There is no leveling system which in my mind made Legends great. No one wants to remember 4 different button combos for the wizards different spells. I get that the developer was trying to do something new but they left out all of the parts that made Legends great. The art style is well done I will give them that but the characters dialogue is to childish and made it seem like they were trying to force in anything that would make them sound whitty at any moment.
Awesome game. Just my type of hack and slash game. Fast paced game. Just need more dungeons and more boss mechanics.
I shot the food :/

All of us growing up in the golden age of standup arcade games remember the beast of a machine Gauntlet was. 4 player coop was unheard of at the time and boy did we like it. So this new rendition of Gauntlet takes that basic formula and steps it up a notch by giving each hero some new skills that gives it a much more modern hack 'n slash feel. And it works. It manages to hold a nostalgic presence while still feeling refreshingly new. They've added some character level ups to keep it interesting and there is even a difficulty setting if you feel like adding a little more challenge.  The biggest shortcoming with Gauntlet is the disproportionate skill set when it comes to the Wizard. He has way too many abilities and other cool effects than anyone else, so playing anyone else feels kind of under whelming. The other significant blemish is its short campaign length. The first playthrough is fun and exciting, but it quickly loses luster on subsequent playthroughs.  The new Gauntlet is indeed fun and best experienced in a full 4-player cooperative, but the game eventually gets stale due to it's short levels and repetitive game play--kind of like the original.

This stays true to the arcade version while modernizing it enought to give it a fresh new feel. I love it.   There's much fun to be had. Racing to get the gold before your friends do. Screaming at the person who shot your health. Laughing as everyone runs from death in oposite directions. Yep, I cannot wait until we play our next round.  Grab four friends and have yourself a blast.  Update: I am close to 11 hours played and I am done for now. In that time I have beaten the game with my friends. While I had a great time, I feel like I need to let it sit for a while before I give it another go. I still think it is worth full price, I just thought I should warn people who might be expecting a longer game.

I originally played Gauntlet 2 on the old Commodore 64. I was super excited when this came out, and bought it.   The humor is spot on and several times my friends and I almost fell out of our chair laughing at some of the dialogue.   Though this isn't quite as unbeatable as the originals with near infinite levels, it's still a great kick-back-and-enjoy game.  Animation and artwork are great, dialogue is great, and tracking acheivment scores and stuff in game is nice. There's also another great minigame in there about who can steal the crown from their friends the most though, and also being a jerk and shooting the food before your friends get it when they're about to die.

Bought a 4 pack to play with my friends, continuously disconnects in the middle of the game. Wouldn't recommend this game, since it's meant to be played in a group.  Hope they'll fix the connection issue, game looks like it had potential.

Gauntlet is a game worth devoting yourself into for at least a 100h. There is so much more skill and variety than meets the eye. It's one of those games that is easy to get into, but at the same time hard to master. Gauntlet also has great replay value with several weapons on each class, several campaign difficulties and an endless mode. It's a game that is largely based on co-op, but at the same time a game in which there is a huge difference bettween a skilled player and a newbie. Meaning, this is a great co-op game, but also a challeging while not frustraring, at least for the most part, single player game.   If you're into games that have a lot of replay value, collectibles, take skill and have a rather ''existant'' community, then by all means buy gauntlet.   All that aside, it's also a fun game to just mess around in with a few buddies on a lazy weekend.   As a final note, this review is not say that gauntlet is a perfect game. It has its cons, bugs and there are things in the game which may seem ''slightly overpowered'' to newer players and some veterans alike. But when you look past all the non-sense some people claim about class balance issues, there lies a game worth investing time into.  Tl;Dr +1

Gauntlet looks like an amazing arpg at first, but it happens to be extremely repetitive.  There are only 3 different environments, no other weapons, no real inventory and the kind of maps you are exploring are always the same for every cave. This is what killed the game for me.   The graphics are nice and the game feels good, but it is very short lasting. For me it was kind of fun for about 2 hours, then it became annoying.  Buy it only if you really love simplistic arpgs and arcade games and if it is on a heavy discount!

I picked up the 2014 version of Gauntlet. I've given the game 15 hours so far since its release so I believe I can make an honest assessment of game from both the nostalgic (I put at least $300 into the original arcade version) and modern game design and playing perspectives. Keep in mind I play this with a keyboard and mouse (Razer Naga).  The Good  1. The game play and design are polished with a few exceptions. The game feels like Gauntlet in 2014 and that is a good thing. The same run around, find keys, open doors, get potions, and the characters and narrator are all there from the original. What has changed is the fun factor and a much shorter game. The characters do more, they are flashier and more unique, and they feel solid when played. Questor the Elf definitely has the easiest playstyle, followed by Thyra the Valkyrie, Thor the Warrior, and finally Merlin the Wizard who is definitely the hardest to play.  2. I found myself enjoying Thyra for the best balance of defense and offense. Thyra has great movement, can block any attack (yes any, even the end boss), and has a great offense as well. I suggest for starting players if you want to get into the fray, choose Thyra first.  3. The mastery levels are nice touch and I really like how they build your character up. You have to choose before you go in whether you are going for no deaths or to dying a million times on purpose.  4. $20 is about the perfect price for the game. I can honestly say I am glad I bought it.  The (Somewhat) Bad  1. Numerous bugs still exist in the game (crashes at times, sound cuts out, visual bugs). Luckily these aren't game-breaking.  2. The camera tries hard to be there for you but currently it leads to more deaths than to give you a clear view of the game. In reality I wish each player had their own screen to look at (e.g. Diablo 3) versus the 3/4-view that traps players.  3. Not being able to check your mastery progression at any time in the game is very annoying. A key to do this needs to be added.  4. Merlin plays too much like Magicka (another Arrowhead product). I programmed my Razer Naga to switch between the nine spells he has and it then became much easier to play. My guess is a lot of other people are going to do the same thing.  5. Cosmetic items are essentially worthless. I'd rather see that you have to buy new gear with better attributes after finishing a difficulty to do better in the harder difficulties than have just a look that nobody cares about.  6. Mastery progression is way too high of a curve at times - it's a ploy for replay value. I do not want to go from 2,000 to 8,000 just for 5% more of an attribute.  7. The game is too short. Normal is completed within 5 hours with a halfway decent team of players. Hopefully Arrowhead now that they have our money have a plan for future content.  8. You are forced into being only one of the four characters. While this mimics the original arcade, in this day and age I shouldn't be forced to play Merlin if I don't want to. Again, this needs to be changed to allow multiple people to live out their Legolas dreams if they wish.  The Ugly  1. The game has no way to chat with other players so you spend a lot of your time in public games using the emotes to try and cajole other players to go the way they need to go, or for you to move due to the camera getting you stuck.  2. The world leader-board was hacked within one hour of release. Currently there are players hacking to over 1.9 trillion points in single player mode. Arrowhead has yet as of this review to respond to a plan to either secure the boards or (as I've suggested on the Steam forums) remove them entirely until they have a way to fix them.  Conclusion  If you are looking for a game that can help you pass some time and is casual, then Gauntlet is definitely the kind of game to lead to a night of fun. If you are looking for something more robust and long-term then this is not the game you are looking for; I would suggest another Action RPG such as Path of Exile or Diablo 3.

Looking for a fun, multiplayer arena brawler for friends? Then move along. There are far better ones out there. Gauntlet was about frantically running around a maze, fighting off the oncoming hoard of enemies, and trying to seek an exit. Gauntlet Legends was about exploring stages, over the top attacks, huge bosses, and playing as a chicken. New Gauntlet is about walking around muddy-brown areas that all look the same, getting into one locked arena after another until you reach the end. Occassionally you have to run from Death and his wonky hit box. Seriously, though.. all previous Gauntlets are bright, gaudy affairs. This one is all browns and greys.  Most egregious to me, though, is that the game can't detect my PS2 Dual Shock 2 controller. That's not that it detects it and won't let me remap buttons, but that the game says 'is this a 360 controller? No? Then there is no controller'. Which is a load of crap in the modern world of PC gaming.  And while spell slinging as the Wizard can be fun, there's a game out there that can do it better (Magicka). In fact, any good point I can think of about Gauntlet is done better by another game.
It was fun for a single playthrough, but after beating it once I had no desire to play it again. Not a bad game, just no replayability IMO.

Not really the game for me. I'll try again on Easy mode tomorrow but Normal just kicked my ♥♥♥♥. I'm not a huge fan of hack'n'slash to start with but I do really enjoy it on occasion. Constant deaths on the first level though just destroyed my confidence in my ability to play the game. I can see how some people who are more into hardcore games and don't get frustrated easily with death after death would enjoy it but I have more fun with progression.

A fantastic revamp of a fantastic classic. Gauntlet is quite possibly the most fun I have had killing skeletons, orcs, deamons and the like.  With four (five with dlc) characters to play, who all play differently, you can enjoy hours of slaying. Or, better yet, hop in with your friends and really start harming bodies.  With the Slayer Edition, this game has gotten even better. Different abilities, new talismans, and a more interesting layout. What's not to love?  If you enjoy 'top down' games, this is a must. If you enjoy somewhat retro advanture/hack and slash games, this is a must. And if you have enjoyed any previous Gauntlet game, how have you not already bought this?
Has a feel like the old games while introducing plenty of new features.   It's Unique. Infuriating. Fun.   Reminds me of the 8-bit days.

I remember playing Gauntlet Legends on the Dreamcast like it was yesterday. Vibrant colors, outdoorsy environments and good ole' local multiplayer options.  Years later and we get this game, it takes a more darker approach with more features - underground dungeons, caves, with a more matured art style. Add some upgrade components and online multiplayer. However, it keeps that same fun-factor by engaging us in addictive gameplay and dark/sarcastic humor.  I feel like I could play this game forever and not get tired. There are 4 characters (5 if you purchase the Necromancer dlc) and each character feels totally different changing the experience.

It is really fun.  But be careful, it is not cheap for how fast it gets repetitive. I believe that more updates would suit this game well.  So far I finished the normal mode and tried a bit of the colesseum and that is where things get fun and complicated.  Get it, and find 3 friends to play with you, you'll have a blast!

The Slayer Edition is the proper version of Gauntlet. The game is a carefully balanced eminently playable *real* game; you never get the sense that any challenge is unfair or gimmicky. The screen is still 'shared', as if all players are bound to a single screen, however it is something you can get used to. Somehow - perhaps only illusory - it seems less of a problem in the Slayer Edition.  Looking forward to more playable characters, new equipment, new enemies, and new adventures. The developers deserve their price on this one.

Gauntlet is a reboot of the 1985 classic arcade game. The 1985 version was memorable for having four characters: Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf. Many people pour quarter after quarter to play this game since it was so addictive. The four characters are back with the same abilities that will remind Gauntlet veterans of what it was like back in the day.  This game offers modes in single player, multiplayer, and four player co-op. You will have to complete three floors of dungeons in each coliseum to unlock new group of floors. The dungeons are diverse enough and you can accidentally shoot foods like in the original. It does get tedious going through the same dungeons after dying and using up skull coins to get a new life. Once you run out of skull coins you will have to start from the first floor regardless of the floor you were in when you died. So, there are no save points on any floor.  Gauntlet also tries to be a little RPG by including Masteries. The Masteries represent the progression of the character you have chosen to play. Believe it or not, dying many times is considered an achievement. Other achievements include taking a lot of damage and using specific moves more than others. It looks to me like the character progression turns out not to be that important since the game is about shooting your way through the dungeons.  The gameplay is interesting when playing co-op or multiplayer. You can shoot each other by accident with friendly fire and that can cause some interesting friction between the players. The layout of the dungeons contains many cranks that you can turn to be able to advance to other parts of the dungeon. It is necessary to get used to being attacked by packs of monsters. In many cases you will have to destroy shacks that summon the monsters since destroying the shacks is the only way to keep more monsters from coming. Sometimes the sorcerers add to the challenge by regenerating the health of a shack with their staves and it will be up to you to kill the sorcerer before destroying the shack.  The controls are easy enough to understand: they are as simple as WASD and the mouse. Playing with ranged characters such as the Elf and the Wizard take more practice than playing with characters that fight in close quarters. I think Gauntlet is more fun when playing either multiplayer or co-op than single player.  The people who experience the original Gauntlet will find this reboot entertaining because of the classic characters and the diverse dungeons. However, if you are a diehard RPG fan looking for deep character customization and progression, you may not like Gauntlet as much as the Gauntlet fans. I think that it is best experienced with other players in multiplayer and co-op modes. The single player mode feels a little boring. This reboot looks better than previous iterations of Gauntlet games that were made after that 1985 original.  My Score: 7/10

A 'Diablo lite'.  Manages to capture a portion of the feeling of the 1985 original. However, by today's standards the game doesn't offer much variety. This does have the benefit of new players being able to jump right in to play with old players' characters, as a new character can be almost as useful as an old one. The flipside is that character development doesn't offer much incentive to keep playing.  The campaign is a bit short, I'd estimate it will be over in 6-8 hours, but for 20 Eur it's an okay deal and the harder difficulty levels can extend its lifetime a bit.  The real meat of the game is the co-op. The more friends you play with, the more fun you have, and although the game itself doesn't offer voice chat, using it is definitely recommended.  At the time of the release the game seemed a bit unpolished and suffered from some cosmetic bugs (the end level mastery achievement descriptions seemed to have some wonky numbers) and some other small annoyances (enemies get rarely stuck inside obstacles making them difficult to kill, no text or voice chat etc.). Nothing gamebreaking though, and they'll hopefully be fixed in future updates.  In conclusion, I wouldn't recommend this for single players, but groups of friends will have a blast. I was reasonably interested to hear that a new Gauntlet game was in the pipeline BUT at that stage I didn't know which pipeline it was in. I hoped it wouldn't be coming from the same one which has blurted forth the gaming equivalent of hot, liquid turds in the name of Gauntlet since the 1980's.  It seems that instead of serving us up complete effluent they have instead managed some kind of plumbing tomfoolery which has resulted in the effluent being mixed with cool, pure water. The resulting fluid can fill a glass but it is possibly not a glass one would choose to drink from.   Some of the benefits of the game...  1) Graphics are nice and (vaguely) evocative of the original game. Nothing looks bad and the game runs well. Everything looks reasonable for an arpg, tbh. Fairly stereotypical but then Gauntlet was pretty much first on the block for this kind of thing. However, there is little to no variation within a dungeon 'set', which isn't in line with the original, there are just themed 'worlds' which are not unlike the crap we had to munch through with 'Gauntlet: Dark Legacy'  2) Multiplayer works well, netcode seems tight. Now that the 'cannot connect to Gauntlet online' random messages have ceased thanks to a post release patch, the netcode works well. Compared to something like Magicka which is still, imo, in a broken 'online' state, Gauntlet runs perfectly. No real problems to report, no lag issues as such.   3) It's a good game for a little while, especially for fans of the original BUT this only lasts a short time. One of the key factors of the original was that there were a lot of different dungeons pooled randomly from a larger set, many of which could be flipped and changed in ways by the game before they were presented to the player. No two playthroughs would be quite the same. This is not the case in the new version, with only a few levels being occasionally 'flipped' but they're very familiar whatever way round you do them after a very few playthroughs.  BAD POINTS  1) Skill trees have been added but instead of making the game something one would return to in order to 'level up' items etc we are presented with something that's nothing more than a skin buying interface (buying skins with ingame money does nothing to your character and they are barely visible) and the option to buy 'spells' (more on these on point 2). You can collect more than enough money very quickly to buy all of these things. Also, each upgrade is NOT character specific, with only 2 skills being particular to each character. This is nonsense. It just means, basically, that you're endlessly playing the game to unlock more of the same stuff (unlocks do not migrate across characters)  2) Spells are terrible. 'Potions' in the original Gauntlet worked as 'Smart bombs' which would destroy onscreen monsters, particularly 'Death' (More on this explained in point 3) but instead of keeping them the same the developers saw fit to wangle them into some rubbish kind of 'Special move' enabling fandango. Preposterous. So, basically, you have to have a potion in your possession to perform your Special move. This means players simply signpost points in levels, grind out enough potions then all just launch the same kind of devastating, battle winning special. This renders the game really boring and, as a direct result of how the game progresses coupled with this stupid idea, the 'end of level' bosses actually get progressively easier as the players become more invincible (in chosen situations). It's a really stupid, crappy system. They should have based these Special abilities on kills or a rage meter or something like that and kept potions the same. In the original game, the wizard could clear a screen by firing off a potion, with the other characters doing progressively less damage with them (warrior being least proficient). Potions were more rare, usually, whereas I feel the new version gives too many, with everyone able to just blast out specials by the time you reach the end of a particular dungeon set.  3) Death is rubbish in this game. People who play/played Gauntlet will know what I mean but for the benefit of those not familiar, Death in Gauntlet is a physical character. In the original he would chase the players and steal health unless someone used a potion. Using a potion 'killed' him, for the time being. There could be multiple 'deaths' on one level, though. They were quite fun and an interesting alternative to ploughing through loads of 'nasties'. Anyway, 'Death' is nothing like that in the new version. Instead of being in the main levels, he gets his own set of levels which really DO NOT WORK. They're not much fun and get old very quick. He appears, chases you for a bit, then disappears. This happens as you're pushed through a linear set of rooms and, yeah, gets old. Death is not remotely troublesome, either, and you can simply run round and round him. He even smashes crates/pots by passing over them so you can use him to collect money. He's basically rubbish in this version of the game, pushed into a sidequest of sorts (which is short and lame YET counts as a 'main level')  4) GENERATORS. GENERATORS, FOR CHRISTS SAKES, NOT 'SUMMONING STONES'. JESUS ! WTF !? The summoning stones are a BAD idea. They even sound rubbish. 'GENERATOR' sounds so much more malevolent and directionless. 'Summoning stones' take the place of generators in this version of the game but they're a really lame replacement. In the original, Generators were in place in the level anyway. You could see them from far away. In this version you will usually walk into a room, the doors will shut, and a Summoning Stone will appear. From this, enemies will come and you smash them up then smash the stone. Doors open. Proceed. Pretty lame, tbh. There are no 'levels' of summoning stone, either, whereas the original game had varying strengths of Generator that spewed various strengths of creature. Also, there were ghost generators in the original game. In this game, ghosts are confined to just appearing on the 'death' mini-levels. They just appear in tiny groups, following him. Useless. Gone are the days of masses of monsters (including ghosts, see LEVEL ONE IN THE ORIGINAL GAME FFS) generating and pushing at the backs of doors, instead we get the occasional room that's been 'set up' with standing monsters but nothing like the original dungeons, creaking with scum to be destroyed. It's like everything in this game is just waiting for you to turn up before it'll appear, which takes away from the 'world of absolute violence' vibe that many so loved about the original. Then again, that might just have been me. I'm asian.  5) This is a SHORT game. It's not got anywhere near the replayability of the original and in a couple of playthroughs (or less) you'll most likely have enough gold to max everything on your (not very unique) character. It's really hurt by not having random levels of the kind offered by stuff like Full Mojo Rampage (and many other such games). With no real need (or, perhaps, desire ?) to replay for more xp and to enjoy some different levels, there's little to return to this game for and we, once again, encounter the same problem that has plagued all of the more modern Gauntlet updates. NOT ENOUGH GAME. Why, when the original paved the way for randomising such a large amount of gameplay elements do we have to put up with this NONSENSE ? We were even promised such things in this version of the game but there is no such thing (99% of the time) here.   6) Price. It's too expensive for what it is and the new character should have been free DLC. The base game doesn't contain a fair few things that were promised and just feels, well, way too short and shallow. It's good fun and the engine is sweet, the characters 'play' well and all the new moves are fine but there need to be many more levels to make this worthwhile.  6/10.   I recommend Full Mojo Rampage instead.

This 2014 edition of Gauntlet is a game I want to like, but that's simply impossible. It's a tedious, monotonous game with serious design problems. The game recently got polished into Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, but the problems remained.  Conclusion: looks good, but not worth of any money. Maybe, if you get it for free, or as a part of humble bundle. Otherwise, no.  Regrettably, this game is not fun to play at all.  After 4 to 5 first levels the game starts to repeat itself. First levels are fairly enjoyable, but after that: nothing new. Controlling game characters (4 different + 1 dlc) is not rewarding, because most of the time your character is very hard to spot from the screen. That's because of three of the worst design flaws: walls obstruct your view, the viewpoint (camera) is zoomed out way too far away from your character AND the levels have very few light sources.  Playing the game makes you wish you had binoculars and a flashlight pointed at the screen.  How about multiplayer mode? You need a friend for that, because there is never anyone playing multiplayer otherwise. Once you get online with your friend, you will experience even more design flaws. You think you cannot get motion sickness from a game? I dare you to try this one on multiplayer mode. Have a bucket next to you when you try. I mean, what were the devs thinking? On single-player you have to strain your eyes to be able see your tiny character on a dim screen, and on multiplayer mode the screen jumps and jolts around making sure you'll vomit, or at least get a headache.  Even if I pretend I can endure the flaws I mentioned, the boring map design and clearing a floor after a floor from the same enemies over and over again is just not worth the time. It is very sad to give this game thumbs down, because I really loved previous Gauntlet games, such as Gauntlet: Dark Legacy and the original Gauntlet and Gauntlet 2. Yes, even the original Gauntlet is less monotonous than this one. At least the original Gauntlet had proper level design and a feeling of progress in the game.

When is Gauntlet not like Gauntlet? When it's this version.  This has more in common with a multi-player version of Diablo than it does with Gauntlet.  I played Gauntlet in the arcades back in the day, when it was new, and eagerly awaited it's release for home computers, including Atari ST and zx spectrum and a few others that were around at the time. My friends and I enjoyed the conversion and played it for many hours.  Then came Gauntlet 2 and we were excited all over again, especially when it was released for home enjoyment, and we all spent our waking hours wandering around with different coloured versions of each of the four characters, with Red elf and yellow wizard and blue wizard and green valkyrie, it was a good time had by all without the limitations of one character type availalbe, and often we'd play as four versions of the same character to see how it played.  Now after a few other releases of gauntlet and it's clones over the years on consoles and home computers, we come to this version.  While I wouldn't say it's a bad game at all, to expect it to be like either of the first two Gauntlet games is to meet with dissapointment, and it really does have a lot more in common with diablo 1 or 2, and Diablo's spawned children than the golden Gauntlet of happiness that I still remember clearly and dearly.  There are certain things that tie this title loosely to the Gauntlet of it's title, like 4 characters named after the Gauntlet characters. Food that's fragile and can be destroyed accidentally, and the fact that it all takes place in a dungeon. Certain sounds and phrases are very similar to the original too. But that's it for similarity really. Anything else is from Diablo. There aren't mazes filled with spawners of varying strengths 1-3 (though there are occassional spawners scattered here and there), and there are potions but they are needed to power artifacts which you buy with gold, outside of the levels you play through. The speech is of course clear and everything, but it is missing the dramatic tone that the original sampled speech used to have, and doesn't fit so well. The only characters that shoot anything off are the elf and wizard, with the rest needing to use secondary abilities to do anything beyond bashing/stabbing the monsters. And on the subect of the wizard, I hope you like pressing combinations of buttons/keys to use an ability, out of all the ones he has hidden.  Muti-player is very hit and miss, in that you might find good players that work together, and with due caution, or more usually find completely selfish players who get the party killed and have no other care but for their own selves and getting all the money and food for themselves. Unfortunately there are far more of the second type than the first, which makes for a less than wonderful experience in multi-player, and has made it so that I am hesitant to even consider playing multi-player when (if) I play gauntlet. Too many people playing it as though the other gamers are just tagging along, and then blaming them for being noobs when they die because the selfish individual has taken all the money/food/potions.  All in all, I am not so willing to recommend this version as a Gauntlet game, but I am willing to recommend it as a diablo clone that's cheaper than the average game these days, and I'd not recommend it to any of my friends if they played Gauntlet and were looking for a modern version to have fun with, though hey.. it's a game to fill the quiet moments of the day with dungeons and monsters.

Gauntlet is not a terrible game to kill some time with, especially if you play with friends but if you choose to pick it up I suggest that you only get it on sale. It has too many flaws for me to recommend it at full price.  It strays a bit from the classic titles but is still a pretty simple arcade-style game and does not get too bogged down with overly complex additions. There are some light gear grinds in the game, you have a few different weapons and other items which you can purchase with gold and some cosmetic cloaks you can unlock through arenas, but that is about it. It is pretty easy to get gold in the game although it can be a bit monotonous to grind enough to buy everything. There is a campaign mode with three difficulties but no real story to speak of, not that this type of game needs one. There is also an endless floor mode which starts extremely easy but ramps up to be quite difficult in a hurry.   Endless mode should be where the game shines, unfortunately the levels are terribly unbalanced and you can go through several floors in a row that are easy enough to be boring only to have a floor with a very small room so packed with enemies that it is nearly impossible to kite, making it extremely tedious to proceed. Also the camera in this game is absolutely horrible so if you are playing with friends and you end up kiting in opposite directions it will attempt to keep all of you on screen rather than focusing on your character. This can lead to you being stuck at the very edge of your screen not able to see what is happening around you. I would say the camera was responsible for more of my cooperative play deaths than anything else.  The Death mob is present but works differently than in Gauntlet 2. He takes up quite a bit of screen real estate and has a huge aura which can sometimes make it hard to see other enemies and projectiles. If he touches you it is an instant kill, at least on the classes I have played. This could actually be somewhat fun on long corridors when you are constantly running and killing what you can as you go, but when you get locked into a room with a large number of mobs, spawners and bullet-sponge minibosses and also have death and his giant blob of color to deal with, it stops feeling challenging and just feels cheap.   The old Gauntlet games threw ridiculous hordes at you but the gameplay was just more enjoyable than it is here. If Death was not quite as obnoxious and the camera did not continually cause problems I would find it easier to recommend. If you want an okay coop game that you can get ten or twenty hours out of, pick it up on sale but do not expect too much out of it. If you want to scratch the Gauntlet itch, just go fire up one of the old arcade titles because this game misses that mark.

You know I absolutely LOVED the arcade and N64 versions of Gauntlet so I'm bias as far as that goes but I really have to say that day one bugs really turn me off. Strike one for this company was the ungodly frustrating bugs in Magicka. This is strike two for Arrowhead Game Studios and if the Gauntlet bugs aren't seriously addressed in later releases, they've lost a customer for life.  FAIR WARNING: I'm writing this review with 1.6hrs of gameplay under my belt so draw your own conclusions on what I noticed during my brief time. In complete honesty, after the game crashed 1.6hrs in, I didn't bother loading it up again and played Civ 5 instead. I'm really irked about my ill-Magicka feelings bleeding through onto this review, but that's what happens when you don't address defects in your software.  Pros: Nostalgia, graphics, puzzle environment, online multiplayer, levels load very fast.  Cons: oh boy, here we go... -Full screen video. The game start with your windows start bar displaying. You can change it to full screen but the full screen setting doesn't always stick.  -Games in Progress: You can't join (or have your friends join) a game that has already started. Highly annoying.  -Character Selection: You can't select more than one character type at the same time. i.e. you can't have four warriors at the same time. You should be able to have a red/blue/green/yellow warrior but you no can haz!  -Upon death: I would love to have the ability to change character classes but since I'm locked to one class once I join the game, I can't do that.  -The camera. I played with two other players and all of us were on the same half of the screen, yet, the camera doesn't move to compensate unless you touch the edge of the screen. This leads you to burn up keys that you've collected.  -Auto Fire: When using the mouse, you can hold the left click to auto-fire with the archer, but none of the other characters have an auto-fire ability. This leads to insane amounts of clicking and can get really tiresome. I haven't tested this with my USB Logitech selectable auto-fire controller but I'm going to be forced to use it if this feature doesn't get added.  -Buggy: Random crashes reminiscent of Magicka that turned you off to Magicka in the first place. I was lucky enough to get to unlock level 4 with two of my friends in one sitting before the first crash occurred.  -Collision: Collision should be an option to be turned on or off. It's upsetting when your friend blocks a doorway and you die because can't get past him.  -Random spawn timers: I've died and have had to wait anywhere from 5 seconds to 20 seconds to spawn and have no idea why the timers are different.  -Wizard: The gameplay is challenging enough as it is, and your character is already always on the move dodging enemies, so why introduce 'Magicka style' 3 or 4 button combinations needed to cast a magic spell? It's my opinion that the wizard will be the least used character because of this.  -Warrior and Valkyrie: The HP attributes on these two characters needs to be improved, either that or make the fighting space a lot larger, have have the baddies do less damage, or introduce a slight knock back on every attack.  Hopefully these issues will be addressed in future updates.

A series revived and overall a fantastically fun game; however it's not without it's faults. One, the class selction is limited and because of it you rarely get to play the role you want to play and you'll often see people leave if they don't get the class they want. They should have made two versions of each class like Dark Legacy so people would have more choice and variety for gameplay as the 4 classes get tiring. Two, the items you purchase are merely cosmetic and do nothing, invest your hard earned cash in actives. Three, there is a desperate lack of of levels and variety in the game. This game would thrive off of more unique stages and level creator would be amazing here. Four, the final and most pressing issue, there's a huge lack of communication. In a cooperative game like this it is very difficult to function properly without proper communication; voice chat, a more fleshed out command system, or even a simple chatbox would makes a world difference in improving the game. The thing Gauntlet does right though is gameplay itself. The actives are brilliant, the gameplay is fantastic, coop is fantastic, and the style is gorgeous. In total I think this game is a step in the right direction for the Gauntlet series and I hope it gets expanded upon in the future or gets a sequel that get's it right.   $20 is a steep price for such a simple game, wait until it's about $10 to get your money's worth. Verdict: 7 / 10  The 1980’s Gauntlet characters return in this new era of gaming: Thor the warrior, Thyra the valkyrie, Merlin the wizard and Questor the elf. Each one having their own progression called masteries. As you chop down, skewering, obliterating or sniping foes, the character becomes stronger overtime, even awarded in death too! Relics, a new feature, activated by potions, have different effects on oneself or enemies. Having it on the right the character can make all the difference in heat of battle. The voice acting is a neat touch and nicely done for the characters to feel more lively, especially Questor’s having a Scottish accent.  Unfortunately, the biggest letdown of the game is the length… it’s short. Finished roughly about five hours on the second hardest difficulty. After completing the game, the repetitiveness is harsh because you’ll be playing the same dungeons again, again and again. At that point, you’ll be increasing the character’s masteries. Still, it declines interest and the replay value quite fast.  The developers no less stuck true to the 1980’s Gauntlet feel. With its amount of content and shortness of the game, it’s going to be hard to love the game. I still recommend the game if your looking for some good old hack ‘n’ slash cooperative fun.  And remember… don’t destroy the food.

In short, expect a fun experience from Gauntlet - but don't expect a long one.

Gauntlet does a lot of things right and Arrowhead (the developer) has raised the bar for this type of experience in a lot of ways. Items of note:  No game I've played does a better job of making you feel like you're fighting against unending hordes of enemies. The Dead Rising series comes close, but Gauntlet's core combat mechanics are built around it. Every combat move that a character has is designed with careful consideration to how you would use it in a horde of bad guys, with pros and cons. This isn't always balanced well between the character classes. Let's segue to that:  Gauntlet, unlike its predecessors, only allows you to pick one of each character class. This means there's no Red Wizard and Blue Wizard. There's just Wizard. I understand the purpose of this, and in a lot of ways, it's better for the game. Each class is very different. Unlike previous entries in the series, the classes all play very differently. The control schemes are different, and your primary tactics are different. Forcing players to choose different characters means there are a lot more interesting and varied things happening in the game, and that is undoubtedly cooler. It also prevents exploits that would be plentiful... I can only imagine what 4 of any one class could do if they strategized to take advantage of their strengths. If the game had balanced around the need for that, the characters would have lost some of their most fun and defining abilities in the interest of balance.  However, it means matchmaking online, or even with your friends, can be a bit of a pain because you will undoubtedly have a favorite class. There's also a 75% chance that nobody you're playing with will want to be the Warrior. I beat the game with the Valkyrie (the game tracks progression separately for each character class), but I put in significant time with each class. I can say with some confidence that the Warrior is underpowered and difficult to play. The Valkyrie and the Warrior are the two characters with the most similar control schemes, but the Valkyrie's moves are often more practical and easier to use than the Warrior's. I won't go into depth, but I'll simply recommend that the game is better with 3 players than with 4, assuming nobody plays the Warrior.  The lighting and art style are perfect for the content of the game. The story is forgettable and pointless, but the characters have fun personalities and they spew Left 4 Dead-style quips at each other. The dungeon's master Morak (more like Genorak amirite?) has a sadistic GLaDOS quality, especially when he mocks you for destroying food, and the game is genuinely fun to listen to. They did an excellent job with effects and sound design for giving the player tons of feedback, despite a hugely crowded play-space once the hordes get going.  I would be very happy to recommend Gauntlet, especially for co-op play.

Pros: -Tons of fun if played with a friend or three -Widely differing playstyles based on which character you choose -Very few bugs/issues  Cons: -Solo play can be aggravating at times with how frequently creatures spawn from spawners -Can't remap keybindings (Not much an issue unless you're playing the Wizard) -Fairly repetitive (Similar to Gauntlet Legends, Seven Sorrows, and Dark Legacy) -Very few levels overall (Again, similar to Gauntlet Legends, Seven Sorrows, and Dark Legacy) -No in-game chat (VoIP or text) -Characters seem to have balance issues (Will elaborate below)  Gameplay: 7/10 Graphics: 7/10 Reply Value: 5/10 Overall Rating: 6/10  Worth $20? No Worth $10-15? Absolutely  All in all, the game does a great job in taking you back to an earlier age of gaming where storyline wasn't always paramount nor required. In terms of being a hack and slash game, it also does a great job. However, it falls short in the category for replay value, variety in level design, and overall balance.  Playing solo is do-able with the Valkyrie or Elf (Played through the first four areas, boss included, as the Elf solo on hard), but the Warrior falls far short of where I believe he should or was intended to be. As above, will withhold judgment on the Wizard due to lack of use.  Unless you're playing with friends with some form of communication (VoIP or third-party chat program) don't expect much from PUG groups. As mentioned above, wound up soloing the first boss on hard when a party of 2-4 failed multiple times due to lack of communication.  Character Balance: Warrior - Should have been the frontline tank and brawling damage-dealer of the game. However, any time I've tried to pick him up and play the game on hard he feels more like a mobile punching bag for the enemy masses than a fearsome warrior. His rush ability is okay at knocking enemies down, but the overall utility is lacking compared to the Elf and Valkyrie. Perhaps it'll start to shine when I unlock the ability to leap attack with it.  OPINION - Increase health pool and damage dealt, should help to relieve some of his early-game issues.  Valkyrie - Similar role as the Warrior, except with more mobility and utility. Makes me feel like I'm playing some medieval female Captain America character with the shield throw. Tons of fun overall. Possibly the second-best character in the game next to the Elf at the moment.  OPINION - Replace her sword with a spear and give her a mid-ranged thrust attack.  Wizard - Withholding judgment, haven't played the character outside the tutorial. Not my style.  OPINION - Withheld  Elf - Quite possibly the most powerful character in the game, easily solo'd the entire first chapter of the game right through the boss on hard. Very mobile, very versatile, very deadly. Legolas from LotR, 'nuff said. The few times I've had issues using the Elf were due to my own mistake on where to roll, where to place his bomb, and generally running into stupid situations. Otherwise makes hard mode easy mode.  OPINION - Bomb damage should be halved against creature spawners and have its cooldown increased by 20-30%. Should also have a slightly longer delay after finishing a roll to balance the fact it can pass through ANY enemy.

All you need is friends, if you have friends you can play with, this game unfolds itself to one of very few games on PC that are on par with Nintendo system games in terms of just having fun with friends and competing against friends while always play together as a team. As some reviews here say it's a short game. You can play the normal difficulty through in two or three sessions, every session one of the 3 chapters with 4 sub-chapters with about 4 stages each, depending on how fast you get the puzzles, more complex bossfights and challenging level designs. So you have about 48 stages that are handcrafted and play and look very differently from each other. This is an arcade style game, it's ment to be played when you happen to find half an hour to have leisure time with friends online. Or if you suddenly all got time on your hand and don't know what to play together: This is the perfect game for that. For singleplayer only or if you want to play through a rich story together, i'd say better get another action RPG like Dungeon Siege 3. And before i forget it: Gauntlet is not easy! It is not an easy game, you need brain, a good overview over hectic situations, the ability to hit with skillshots (everything in this game is a skillshot!) and hence, very fast reactions, even when playing together with up to 3 other players. And you'll need to find a way to make quick decisions together as a team, in some cases you will be punished as a team for deciding for different routes or actions at the same time. A good example is a situation where you have less keys than there are doors to unlock and behind some doors there might be more keys. And the UI? It's the best action RPG UI i've ever seen, that even allows for every player's character information to be completely visible on each player's screen simultaneously! You see all your friend's resources, cooldowns, active spells, etc. The UI and hack'n'slash combat are genious, both on par with Diablo 3, at least!

Collecting loot, leveling up, and setting up character builds are two things you won't be doing in Gauntlet, it is a bare bones dungeon crawler. The game allows you to play one of five different classes. The classes are all very different from one another, but within each class there is very little room for customization and different playstyles.   Instead of setting a button layout for the game and fitting each character's abilties into that layout the game opts to give each character a unique feel in addition to skillset. The warrior for example is your standard light hit mapped to one button, hard hit mapped to another, and special skill, and each of those can be stringed into combos. The elf uses a bow and arrow and plays like most top down shooters where you use the right thumbstick to shoot arrows in the direction you aim the stick. Among all the classes the most fun I found to play was the wizard. The wizard has access to 9 spells and they're all done with a different combination of three buttons, it actually ends up being a pretty elegant system for spells as opposed to a spell bar, but it does take a little getting used to.  The character customization seems like an afterthought. Each character can have two relics that they can equip. The relics aren't found, they can only be bought with gold collected throughout the levels. They'll allow you to do things like move faster, freeze enemies around you, put a trail of fire where you walk, and heal the party. There are not very many relics available, only about 9 or so, and they don't really change the game much. To use relics you need to obtain magic bottles so in addition to there not being very many you also won't be using them very often.   There is hardly a story to the game, there's a big bad guy and you have to go kill him, that's about it. In some games this may be a negative, but I don't think most people would really expect a Gauntlet game to be about the story. I'm only stating this as information for those that might expect it to be a primary focus, it's not, and I don't count it against the game.  The game has jump in and jump out of game co-op where everyone has to play one of the five classes, there is no doubling up on classes. It is fun to group up and work through a dungeon together, and on the hardest difficulty it can be hard so everyone has to be on their game to get through. One of the primary aspects of the original Gauntlet games that were important to the experience was competition with your teammates. Who can get through the level with the most gold? Kill the most enemies? This version of Gauntlet doesn't seem to have that aspect for some reason. I think a few factors contribute to this: 1) not much gold to go around, 2) some classes are obviously more powerful than others and will always lead in kills. By making the classes so different they sort of ruined the competitive aspect because of balance problems. What ends up happening is the game is turned into a normal dungeon crawler where the objective is just to survive and beat the level. I think it might have been more fun to include some other competitive aspect in some way with certain types of drops or something.  Gauntlet is a fun game if what you expect out of it is realistic. You aren't going to be getting a high end dungeon crawler loot fest. It is a simplistic, watered down dungeon crawler that should be played with multiple people. I think the $20 asking price is a bit too much for what you get, but this is a great buy for at least 50% off on a sale.

That's this game.  It's not a challenge... It's just keep dying until you can buy enough so you don't. The Gauntlet of old was, at its best, a game of tactics and planning. You were playing alone or with friends against hordes of enemies, setting up choke points, solving puzzles, sweeping a floor in a careful, methodical method, and pressing on. It was a game about tactics, planning, and puzzle solving as much as action. This isn't that game. This game... Just run for the gold, hope you can blast enough enemies to keep some of it. Repeat. Buy upgrades. Repeat.   So, if you like mindless action and lots of dying, go for it. But I can't even really call it Gauntlet. It lacks Gauntlet's spirit.

Let me clarify the thumbs down. This game gets thumbs down because it is not Gauntlet, I will elaborate. The game is a decent hack n slash party game with a fun challenge, but calling it Gauntlet is a lie and is deceiving to fans.   I was excited as ♥♥♥♥ to see this game's trailer, they made it look so pretty and fast paced and fun, bringing back that Nintendo64 gauntlet adventure feeling. Turning that old game on was always like being transported to another gigantic epic adventure with all the unique levels, bosses, tons of items along the way for weapon mutations or familiars that join you. Not to mention items that unlock secret levels or characters, lots of interesting and fun cutscenes, and a wide variety of puzzles to interact with unique to each world.   THIS GAME trades all of that for pretty colours and getting to change your helmet, weapon, a cape, and alternating what potions do, and some spells. This basically negates all of the fun of what Gauntlet was. Your primary focus has now become taking all the gold, which just makes people mad, because without gold, you cannot buy weapons. You are also correct in realizing that no weapons/item purchases mean no variance in your gameplay. All ability and weapon and spell augmentations are tied to weapons or tomes you purchase in the store. Note that not even all of the store items even do anything, most are purely cosmetic.   I mean so yeah, having a unique inventory to your character is cool, and buying your own special ♥♥♥♥ is nice, but…at the cost of what? Well you judge that.   Other things that take away from the game are the fact that you cannot kill death anymore, at least it's more obscure than it was in the original games. Why does using a potion not kill death? Was this some dumb unlockable ability for one hero that he has to buy in the store to be able to do? Before, any character could use a potion to dispel death. Now they have turned levels in which he exclusively appears (no more opening a chest for treasure, no death popping out of a chest!) he is turned into basically an outrun the lava level. It's not timed, but he really enforces you to proceed quite quickly due to following you quickly and being huge.   There are no more worlds, it's a straight shot down, barely any change up of enemy diversity, I felt like I was fighting the same monster the entire game, and there were very few bosses, nothing was themed or engaging. Grind grind, get gold, buy shitx666   Whoo. So, maybe I didn't play this enough? Is there more to this game? Does it open up into everything I am criticizing it for missing? Maybe so, and if so then that's too bad. I invested around 8 good hours with 3-4 fluctuating people involved and it was of the consistent content I have previously described. So if there is more, then frankly that's a damn shame that it would take so long to getting back to a game so timelessly classic as Gauntlet. I understand Gauntlet changed through generations and Midway no longer exists, so clearly the same heart was not in the production of this game. I'm not interested in investing that much time in a game that is nothing what I was told it was. They used key factors reminiscent of the old game to draw you in and cheated people out of how many dollars is this game? 15? 25? 30? I don't know right now, but whatever the price, it's not worth more than 5$ if you call it Gauntlet. Yeah sure you put the music from the old games in, there was a wizard, you shot the food, and you said 'Red wizard needs food badly', but come on, that doesn't make a game.   Like I said, it was a decent party game, and it was enjoyable. I just spent the entire time trying to be entertained like I was with Dark Legacy or Legends, but it never happened. It's like they didn't even try.
